posts.name: Eren
posts.cooked: I’m not a programmer, but I am helping them out by making this post. our programmers have been struggling to get the elevator to work, it works without the encoder, but with the new encoder attached we haven’t been able to get the elevator to move. I believe our encoder is the newest that can be bought for this, all the wiring appears fine, and the CAN IDs are fine. I can maybe get access to our code and post it here soon, but we are seeking reference code in c++ to reference.

posts.name: joemost
posts.cooked:
Happy to help but you need to post your code.

What does double mean in this context, two motors driving your elevator?

Would need to see what motor controllers you are using, how you are using the API. etc.

posts.name: Eren
posts.cooked:
Double refers to a 2 carriage elevator, it is also powered by 2 motors. The programmers from my team sent me these screenshots: PXL_20250514_205406237 1920×2550 371 KB

PXL_20250514_205406237 1920×2550 371 KB

PXL_20250514_205406237 1920×2550 371 KB

posts.name: Dkt01
posts.cooked:
As Joe mentioned, it would help to know the following:

What motors are you using?

What encoder are you using?

Where is the encoder relative to the elevator mechanism and the drive motor(s)?

What is the behavior you’re trying to achieve?

posts.name: Eren
posts.cooked:
We are using 2 Phoenix motors with (I believe) 4 to 1 gear boxes on them, the ctr electronics wcp thoroughbore encoder for 1/2 (I believe it’s the newest cancoder of this type).

The encoder sits on the lowest shaft of the elevator, and really we are just trying to get it to do anything at this point

posts.name: Dkt01
posts.cooked: Looks like you have two motors controlling the same moving component.  You should have one motor act as a follower ( CTRE example ).  Make sure the follower motor is properly inverted if it needs to spin in the opposite direction as the leader

posts.name: Aidan
posts.cooked:
I was able to find the GitHub page for your code (as far as I can tell):

One thing I noticed is that you don’t appear to have any PID applied on the elevator, so it might not be able to move unless you configure the motor pid.

(I’m not the most knowledgeable with C++, so I don’t know how much help I can give)

posts.name: joemost
posts.cooked:
Yeah with no P value, you won’t move.

You could also try with voltage out command to verify that its specifically the pid loop

As a good sanity check too you could log the remote sensor position and veryify it changes if you movr the elevator.

posts.name: Muaz
posts.cooked:
Hi, we’re a c++ team, if you head to the Odometry branch and check out ElevatorSubsystem you’ll find our elevator code that also uses 2 motors and is 2 stage
